question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in entropy when $25 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy is transferred reversibly and isothermally as heat to a large block of iron at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_output:
The entropy change for a reversible, isothermal heat transfer is  

\[
\Delta S=\frac{q_{\text{rev}}}{T}
\]

Here \(q_{\text{rev}} = +25\;\text{kJ}=+2.50\times10^{4}\;\text{J}\) and the temperature of the iron block is  

\[
T = 0^{\circ}\text{C}=273.15\;\text{K}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\Delta S = \frac{2.50\times10^{4}\;\text{J}{\rm K}^{-1}}{273.15\;\text{K}}
        \approx 9.15\times10^{1}\;\text{J}{\rm K}^{-1}
        = 91.5\;\text{J}{\rm K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{91.5}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the standard enthalpy of solution of $\mathrm{AgCl}(\mathrm{s})$ in water from the enthalpies of formation of the solid and the aqueous ions.
llm_output:
The dissolution reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{AgCl(s)}\;\longrightarrow\;\mathrm{Ag^{+}(aq)}+\mathrm{Cl^{-}(aq)}
\]

For a reaction at standard state  

\[
\Delta_{\mathrm{sol}}H^{\circ}= \sum \Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}(\text{products})-
\sum \Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}(\text{reactants})
\]

Using the standard enthalpies of formation (kJ mol\(^{-1}\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}\bigl[\mathrm{AgCl(s)}\bigr] &= -127.0\\
\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}\bigl[\mathrm{Ag^{+}(aq)}\bigr] &= +105.0\\
\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}\bigl[\mathrm{Cl^{-}(aq)}\bigr] &= -167.2
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{\mathrm{sol}}H^{\circ} &=
\bigl[\,\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}(\mathrm{Ag^{+}})+\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}(\mathrm{Cl^{-}})\,\bigr]
-\Delta_{\mathrm f}H^{\circ}(\mathrm{AgCl})\\[4pt]
&= \bigl[105.0 + (-167.2)\bigr] - (-127.0)\\
&= (-62.2) + 127.0\\
&= +64.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{64.8}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in entropy when $25 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy is transferred reversibly and isothermally as heat to a large block of iron at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_output:
The entropy change for a reversible, isothermal heat transfer is  

\[
\Delta S=\frac{q_{\text{rev}}}{T}
\]

where \(q_{\text{rev}} = 25\;\text{kJ}=2.5\times10^{4}\;\text{J}\) and the temperature of the iron block is  

\[
T = 100^{\circ}\text{C}=273.15+100 = 373.15\;\text{K}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\Delta S = \frac{2.5\times10^{4}\ \text{J}}{373.15\ \text{K}}
          \approx 6.70\times10^{1}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
          \approx 67\ \text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{67}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the molar entropy of a constant-volume sample of neon at $500 \mathrm{~K}$ given that it is $146.22 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_output:
The entropy change for an ideal gas at constant volume is  

\[
\Delta S = \int_{T_1}^{T_2}\frac{C_{V,m}}{T}\,dT
        = C_{V,m}\,\ln\!\left(\frac{T_2}{T_1}\right)
\]

For mon  

\[
C_{V,m}= \frac{3}{2}R = \frac{3}{2}(8.314\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})
       = 12.471\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\Delta S = 12.471\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
           \ln\!\left(\frac{500\;\text{K}}{298\;\text{K}}\right)
         = 12.471\;\ln(1.67785)
         \approx 12.471 \times 0.517 \;
         \approx 6.45\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

The molar entropy at 500 K is therefore  

\[
S_{500\;\text{K}} = S_{298\;\text{K}} + \Delta S
                  = 146.22\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
                    + 6.45\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
                  \approx 152.7\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{152.7}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A strip of magnesium of mass $15 \mathrm{~g}$ is placed in a beaker of dilute hydrochloric acid. Calculate the work done by the system as a result of the reaction. The atmospheric pressure is 1.0 atm and the temperature $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\mathrm{Mg(s)}+2\;\mathrm{HCl(aq)}\rightarrow \mathrm{MgCl_2(aq)}+\mathrm{H_2(g)}
\]

produces one mole of \(\mathrm{H_2}\) per mole of Mg.  

Moles of Mg  

\[
n_{\text{Mg}}=\frac{15\;\text{g}}{24.31\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}=0.62\;\text{mol}
\]

so the amount of \(\mathrm{H_2}\) formed is  

\[
n_{\mathrm{H_2}} =0.62\;\text{mol}
\]

At 298 K and 1 atm, the volume of this gas (ideal‑gas approximation) is  

\[
V = nRT/P = (0.62\;\text{mol})(0.082057\;\text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})(298\;\text{K}) = 15.1\;\text{L}
\]

\[
V = 15.1\;\text{L}=1.51\times10^{-2}\;\text{m}^{3}
\]

The expansion work at constant external pressure is  

\[
w = -P\Delta V = -(1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa})(1.51\times10^{-2}\;\text{m}^{3})
      = -1.53\times10^{3}\;\text{J}= -1.5\;\text{kJ}
\]

Hence the work done by the system (negative sign indicates work done on the surroundings) is  

\[
\boxed{-1.5}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in chemical potential of a perfect gas when its pressure is increased isothermally from $1.8 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $29.5 \mathrm{~atm}$ at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the chemical‑potential change on an isothermal pressure change is  

\[
\Delta\mu = RT\ln\frac{P_2}{P_1}.
\]

At \(T = 40^{\circ}\mathrm{C313.15\;\text{K}\),

\[
RT = (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(313.15\;\text{K})
     = 2.603\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}.
\]

The pressure ratio is  

\[
\frac{P_2}{P_1}= \frac{29.5\;\text{atm}}{1.8\;\text{atm}} = 16.3889,
\qquad
\ln\frac{P_2}{P_1}= \ln(16.3889)= 2.797.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta\mu = (2.603\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1})(2.797)
          = 7.28\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
          = 7.28\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{7.28}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: A gas at $250 \mathrm{~K}$ and $15 \mathrm{~atm}$ has a molar volume 12 per cent smaller than that calculated from the perfect gas law. Calculate the molar volume of the gas.
llm_output:
The ideal‑gas molar volume at the given conditions is  

\[
V_{\text{ideal}}=\frac{RT}{P}
      =\frac{(0.082057\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{atm}\,\text{K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1})(250\;\text{K})}{15\;\text{atm}}
      =\frac{20.51425}{15}=1.3676\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

The real gas volume is \(12\%\) smaller:

\[
V_{\text{real}}=V_{\text{ideal}}\,(1-0.12)=0.88\,V_{\text{ideal}}
               =0.88\times 1.3676=1.2035\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

Rounded to appropriate significant figures,

\[
\boxed{1.20}\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the final temperature of a sample of argon of mass $12.0 \mathrm{~g}$ that is expanded reversibly and adiabatically from $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $273.15 \mathrm{~K}$ to $3.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$.
llm_output:
For a reversible adiabatic (isentropic) expansion of an ideal gas  

\[
T_2 = T_1\left(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\right)^{\gamma-1},
\qquad 
\gamma = \frac{C_p}{C_v}= \frac{5}{3}\;(\text{monatomic Ar})
\]

\[
\gamma-1 = \frac{5}{3}-1 = \frac{2}{3}
\]

\[
\frac{V_1}{V_2}= \frac{1.0\ \text{dm}^3}{3.0\ \text{dm}^3}= \frac{1}{3}
\]

\[
T_2 = 273.15\ \text{K}\;\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2/3}
      = 273.15\ \text{K}\;\times 0.480749
      \approx 1.31\times10^{2}\ \text{K}
\]

\[
\boxed{131}\ \text{K}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. For a van der Waals gas, $\pi_T=a / V_{\mathrm{m}}^2$. Calculate $\Delta U_{\mathrm{m}}$ for the isothermal expansion of nitrogen gas from an initial volume of $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to $24.8 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.

Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A sample of $4.50 \mathrm{~g}$ of methane occupies $12.7 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $310 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the work that would be done if the same expansion occurred reversibly.
llm_output:
The reversible work for an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas is  

\[
w_{\text{rev}}=-\int_{V_1}^{V_2}P\,\mathrm{d}V
           =-nRT\int_{V_1}^{V_2}\frac{\mathrm{d}V}{V}
           =-nRT\ln\!\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right).
\]

The amount of methane is  

\[
n=\frac{4.50\ \text{g}}{M_{\text{CH}_4}}=
   \frac{4.50}{16.04}\ \text{mol}=0.2805\ \text{mol}.
\]

At the given temperature \(T=310\ \text{K}\),

\[
nRT = (0.2805\ \text{mol})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(310\ \text{K})
      = 7.23\times10^{2}\ \text{J}.
\]

If the gas expands reversibly to twice its initial volume \((V_2 = 2V_1)\),

\[
w_{\text{rev}} = -\,nRT\ln 2
                = -(7.23\times10^{2}\ \text{J})\,(0.6931)
                = -5.01\times10^{2}\ \text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-5.0\times10^{2}}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The enthalpy of vaporization of chloroform $\left(\mathrm{CHCl}_3\right)$ is $29.4 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at its normal boiling point of $334.88 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the entropy of vaporization of chloroform at this temperature.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a modern steam turbine that operates with steam at $300^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharges at $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
Calculate the mass of water vapour present in a room of volume $400 \mathrm{m}^3$ that contains air at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ on a day when the relative humidity is 60 percent.'
llm_output:
The water‑vapour density at the actual partial pressure is obtained from the ideal‑gas law  

\[
\rho = \frac{M\,p}{R_u T}
\]

where  

* \(M = 18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1}\) (molar mass of \(\mathrm{H_2O}\)),  
* \(R_u = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\),  
* \(T = 27^{\circ}\text{C}=300.15\;\text{K}\).

The saturation vapour pressure at \(27^{\circ}\text{C}\) is given by  

\[
p_{\text{sat}} = 0.61078\; \exp\!\left(\frac{17.27\,T}{T+237.3}\right)\;\text{kPa}
          \approx 0.61078\; \exp\!\left(\frac{17.27\times27}{27+237.3}\right)
          \approx 3.57\;\text{kPa}.
\]

With a relative humidity of \(60\%\),

\[
p = 0.60\,p_{\text{sat}} \approx 0.60\times 3.57\;\text{kPa}=2.14\;\text{kPa}
      = 2.14\times10^{3}\;\text{Pa}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\rho = \frac{0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1}\times 2.14\times10^{3}\;\text{Pa}}
            {8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\times 300.15\;\text{K}}
      \approx 1.55\times10^{-2}\;\text{kg m}^{-3}.
\]

The mass of water vapour in the \(V = 400\;\text{m}^{3}\) room is  

\[
m = \rho V \approx (1.55\times10^{-2}\;\text{kg m}^{-3})(400\;\text{m}^{3})
    \approx 6.2\;\text{kg}.
\]

\[
\boxed{6.2}\ \text{kg}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The enthalpy of vaporization of chloroform $\left(\mathrm{CHCl}_3\right)$ is $29.4 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at its normal boiling point of $334.88 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the entropy change of the surroundings.
A vessel of volume $22.4 \mathrm{dm}^3$ contains $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2$ at $273.15 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate their total pressure.
llm_output:
The total number of moles in the vessel is  

\[
n_{\text{total}} = 2.0\ \text{mol H}_2 + 1.0\ \text{mol N}_2 = 3.0\ \text{mol}.
\]

Using the ideal‑gas equation \(PV = nRT\) with \(R = 0.082057\ \text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\),

\[
P = \frac{n_{\text{total}}RT}{V}
   = \frac{(3.0\ \text{mol})(0.082057\ \text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})(273.15\ \text{K})}{22.4\ \text{L}}
   = \frac{3.0 \times 22.414\ \text{L·atm}}{22.4\ \text{L}}
   = 3.0\ \text{atm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{3.0}\ \text{atm}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Suppose that $3.0 \mathrm{mmol} \mathrm{N}_2$ (g) occupies $36 \mathrm{~cm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$ and expands to $60 \mathrm{~cm}^3$. Calculate $\Delta G$ for the process.
llm_output:
The Gibbs‑energy change for an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas is  

\[
\Delta G = nRT\ln\frac{P_2}{P_1}=nRT\ln\frac{V_1}{V_2}
\]

where  

\[
n = 3.0\;\text{mmol}=0.003\;\text{mol},\qquad 
R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\qquad 
T = 300\;\text{K},
\]
\[
V_1 = 36\;\text{cm}^3,\qquad V_2 = 60\;\text{cm}^3\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\frac{V_1}{V_2}= \frac{36}{60}=0.60.
\]

\[
\ln\!\left(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\right)=\ln(0.60)=-0.5108.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta G = (0.003)(8.314)(300)\bigl[-0.5108\bigr]
          = -3.8\;\text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-3.8}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an adiabatic reversible expansion.
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the entropy change for any reversible process is  

\[
\Delta S_{\text{sys}} = nC_{p}\ln\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-nR\ln\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}
\]

where \(n\) is the amount of substance, \(C_{p}\) the molar heat capacity at constant pressure and \(R\) the gas constant.

---

### 1. Amount of substance  

\[
n=\frac{m}{M}= \frac{14\;\text{g}}{28\;\text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.50\;\text{mol}
\]

### 2. Properties of \( \mathrm{N_2} \) (diatomic, 298 K)  

\[
C_{v}= \frac{5}{2}R,\qquad C_{p}=C_{v}+R=\frac{7}{2}R,\qquad 
\gamma=\frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}}=\frac{7}{5}=1.40
\]

### 3. Final state of a reversible adiabatic expansion that doubles the volume  

\[
V_{2}=2V_{1}
\]

For a reversible adiabatic process  

\[
P V^{\gamma}= \text{const},\qquad T V^{\gamma-1}= \text{const}
\]

Hence  

\[
P_{2}=P_{1}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma}=1\;\text{bar}\;(1/2)^{1.40}=0.379\;\text{bar}
\]

\[
T_{2}=T_{1}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma-1}=298\;\text{K}\;(1/2)^{0.40}=226\;\text{K}
\]

### 4. Entropy change of the gas  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta S_{\text{sys}} &=
nC_{p}\ln\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}}-nR\ln\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}\\[2mm]
&=0.50\left(\frac{7}{2}R\right)\ln\frac{226}{298}
-0.50R\ln\frac{0.379}{1}\\[2mm]
&=0.50\,(3.5R)\,(-0.277)-0.50R\,(-0.970)\\[2mm]
&\approx -4.03\;\text{J K}^{-1}+4.03\;\text{J K}^{-1}=0\;\text{J K}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

Because the process is reversible and adiabatic, no heat is exchanged with the surroundings, so  

\[
\Delta S_{\text{surr}} = -\frac{Q}{T}=0 .
\]

---

\[
\boxed{\Delta S_{\text{total}} = 0\ \text{J K}^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When a certain freon used in refrigeration was expanded adiabatically from an initial pressure of $32 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to a final pressure of $1.00 \mathrm{~atm}$, the temperature fell by $22 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the Joule-Thomson coefficient, $\mu$, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, assuming it remains constant over this temperature range.
llm_output:
The Joule‑Thomson coefficient is defined by  

\[
\mu = \left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial P}\right)_H \approx \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta P},
\]

where the temperature change \(\Delta T\) and pressure change \(\Delta P\) are taken for the adiabatic (constant‑enthalpy) expansion.

\[
\Delta T = T_{\text{final}}-T_{\text{initial}} = -22\ \text{K},
\qquad 
\Delta P = P_{\text{final}}-P_{\text{initial}} = 1.00\ \text{atm}-32\ \text{atm}= -31\ \text{atm}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\mu = \frac{\Delta T}{\Delta P}= \frac{-22\ \text{K}}{-31\ \text{atm}}
      = \frac{22}{31}\ \text{K atm}^{-1}
      \approx 0.71\ \text{K atm}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.71}\ \text{K atm}^{-1}
\]

question:
Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The volume of a certain liquid varies with temperature as
$$
V=V^{\prime}\left\{0.75+3.9 \times 10^{-4}(T / \mathrm{K})+1.48 \times 10^{-6}(T / \mathrm{K})^2\right\}
$$
where $V^{\prime}$ is its volume at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate its expansion coefficient, $\alpha$, at $320 \mathrm{~K}$.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The standard enthalpy of combustion of solid phenol $\left(\mathrm{C}_6 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}\right)$ is $-3054 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}_{\text {and }}$ its standard molar entropy is $144.0 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard Gibbs energy of formation of phenol at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_output:
The standard Gibbs energy of formation of phenol can be obtained from the combustion data.

1. **Combustion reaction (solid phenol):**  

\[
\mathrm{C_6H_5OH(s)}+8\,\mathrm{O_2(g)}\rightarrow 6\,\mathrm{CO_2(g)}+3\,\mathrm{H_2O(l)}
\]

2. **Standard entropies (J K\(^{-1}\) mol\(^{-1}\))**  

\[
\begin{aligned}
S^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH}) &= 144.0\\
S^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2}) &= 213.7\\
S^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)}) &= 69.9\\
S^\circ(\mathrm{O_2}) &= 205.0
\end{aligned}
\]

3. **Entropy change of combustion**

\[
\Delta S^\circ_{\text{comb}}=
\bigl[6(213.7)+3(69.9)\bigr]-\bigl[144.0+8(205.0)\bigr]
= -292.1\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

4. **Gibbs energy change of combustion**

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^\circ_{\text{comb}}&=
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}}-T\Delta S^\circ_{\text{comb}}\\
&= -3054\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
- (298.15\ \text{K})(-0.2921\ \text{kJ K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})\\
&= -3054\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}+87.1\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
&= -2966.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

5. **Standard Gibbs energies of formation (kJ mol\(^{-1}\))**

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2(g)}) &= -394.4\\
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)}) &= -237.13\\
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{O_2(g)}) &= 0
\end{aligned}
\]

6. **Relation between ΔG of combustion and ΔG of formation**

\[
\Delta G^\circ_{\text{comb}}=
\bigl[6\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2})+3\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O})\bigr]
-\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})
\]

Insert the numbers:

\[
-2966.9=
\bigl[6(-394.4)+3(-237.13)\bigr]-\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})
\]

\[
-2966.9=
-3077.79-\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH})
\]

\[
\Delta G_f^\circ(\mathrm{C_6H_5OH}) = -110.9\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{-111}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a primitive steam engine operating on steam at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharging at $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A sample of $4.50 \mathrm{~g}$ of methane occupies $12.7 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $310 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the work done when the gas expands isothermally against a constant external pressure of 200 Torr until its volume has increased by
$3.3 \mathrm{dm}^3$.
llm_output:
The work done by the gas during an isothermal expansion against a constant external pressure is  

\[
w = -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V .
\]

**Convert the external pressure to pascals**

\[
P_{\text{ext}} = 200\;\text{Torr}\;
\frac{101325\;\text{Pa}}{760\;\text{Torr}}
= 200 \times 133.322\;\text{Pa}
= 2.6664\times10^{4}\;\text{Pa}.
\]

**Convert the volume change to cubic metres**

\[
\Delta V = 3.3\;\text{dm}^{3}=3.3\;\text{L}=3.3\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^{3}.
\]

**Calculate the work**

\[
\begin{aligned}
w &= -\left(2.6664\times10^{4}\;\text{Pa}\right)
      \left(3.3\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^{3}\right) \\
  &= -8.80\times10^{1}\;\text{J}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{-8.80\times10^{1}}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the maximum non-expansion work per mole that may be obtained from a fuel cell in which the chemical reaction is the combustion of methane at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_output:
The maximum non‑expansion work obtainable from a fuel cell equals the standard Gibbs‑energy change of the combustion reaction:

\[
\mathrm{CH_4(g)}+2\;\mathrm{O_2(g)}\;\longrightarrow\;\mathrm{CO_2(g)}+2\;\mathrm{H_2O(l)}
\]

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= \sum \nu_i \Delta G_f^{\circ}(\text{products})-\sum \nu_i \Delta G_f^{\circ}(\text{reactants})
\]

Using the standard Gibbs‑energy of formation values at 298 K  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{CH_4(g)}) &= -50.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta G_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{CO_2(g)}) &= -394.4\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}= -394.4\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta G_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{H_2O(l)}) &= -237.13\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\\
\Delta G_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{O_2(g)}) &= 0
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G^{\circ} &=\big[-394.4+2(-237.13)\big]-\big[-50.8+2(0)\big] \\
&= -868.66 + 50.8 \\
&= -817.86\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

The maximum useful (non‑expansion) work that can be obtained per mole of methane is the magnitude of \(-\Delta G^{\circ}\):

\[
\boxed{818}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in Gibbs energy of $35 \mathrm{~g}$ of ethanol (mass density $0.789 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ ) when the pressure is increased isothermally from $1 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $3000 \mathrm{~atm}$.
llm_output:
The Gibbs energy change for a condensed (incompressible) phase under an isothermal pressure change is  

\[
\Delta G =\int_{P_1}^{P_2} V\,dP \approx V\,(P_2-P_1),
\]

where \(V\) is the molar (or here, total) volume of the sample.

---

### 1. Volume of the ethanol sample  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{mass} &= 35\;\text{g}=0.035\;\text{kg},\\[2mm]
\rho &=0.789\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3}=0.789\times10^{3}\;\frac{\text{kg}}{\text{m}^3}=789\;\frac{\text{kg}}{\text{m}^3},\\[2mm]
V &=\frac{m}{\rho}= \frac{0.035\;\text{kg}}{789\;\text{kg m}^{-3}}
   =4.44\times10^{-5}\;\text{m}^3 .
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2. Pressure change  

\[
\Delta P = (3000-1)\,\text{atm}=2999\;\text{atm}.
\]

Since \(1\;\text{atm}=1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}\),

\[
\Delta P = 2999 \times 1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}
        = 3.0387\times10^{8}\;\text{Pa}.
\]

---

### 3. Gibbs‑energy change  

\[
\Delta G = V\,\Delta P
          = (4.44\times10^{-5}\;\text{m}^3)(3.0387\times10^{8}\;\text{Pa})
          = 1.35\times10^{4}\;\text{J}
          = 13.5\;\text{kJ}.
\]

The increase in pressure raises the Gibbs energy, so \(\Delta G\) is positive.

\[
\boxed{13.5}\;\text{kJ}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an isothermal reversible expansion.
llm_output:
The entropy change for a reversible isothermal expansion of an ideal gas is  

\[
\Delta S = nR\ln\frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} .
\]

The volume is doubled, so \(\displaystyle \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} = 2\).

Moles of nitrogen:

\[
n = \frac{m}{M} = \frac{14\ \text{g}}{28.0\ \text{g mol}^{-1}} = 0.50\ \text{mol}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta S = (0.50\ \text{mol})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})\ln 2
        = 0.5 \times 8.314 \times 0.6931\ \text{J K}^{-1}
        \approx 2.88\ \text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.88\ \text{J K}^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta H$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_output:
The two copper blocks have the same mass and the same specific heat, so at thermal equilibrium the temperature will be the average of the initial temperatures  

\[
T_{\text{eq}}=\frac{(373.15\ \text{K})+(273.15\ \text{K})}{2}=323.15\ \text{K}=50^{\circ}\text{C}.
\]

Each block changes its temperature by \( \Delta T = 50\ \text{K}\).  
The heat lost by the hot block is  

\[
q_{\text{hot}}=m\,c_p\,\Delta T
            = (10.0\ \text{kg})(0.385\ \text{J g}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(10^{3}\ \text{g kg}^{-1})(-50\ \text{K})
            = -1.925\times10^{5}\ \text{J}.
\]

The cold block gains the same amount of heat, \(q_{\text{cold}}=+1.925\times10^{5}\ \text{J}\).  

Since the container is isolated, the total heat exchange for the system is zero, and for solids the enthalpy change equals the heat exchanged at constant pressure (the \(pV\) term is negligible). Hence  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{system}} = q_{\text{hot}} + q_{\text{cold}} = 0.
\]

\[
\boxed{0\ \text{J}}
\]

question: In an attempt to determine an accurate value of the gas constant, $R$, a student heated a container of volume $20.000 \mathrm{dm}^3$ filled with $0.25132 \mathrm{g}$ of helium gas to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and measured the pressure as $206.402 \mathrm{cm}$ of water in a manometer at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the value of $R$ from these data. (The density of water at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is $0.99707 \mathrm{g} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}$; a manometer consists of a U-shaped tube containing a liquid. One side is connected to the apparatus and the other is open to the atmosphere. The pressure inside the apparatus is then determined from the difference in heights of the liquid.)
llm_output:
The ideal‑gas equation  

\[
pV=nRT
\]

gives  

\[
R=\frac{pV}{nT}.
\]

---

### 1.  Amount of gas  

Helium mass  

\[
m = 0.25132\;\text{g}
\]

Molar mass of He  

\[
M_{\mathrm{He}} = 4.002602\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n=\frac{m}{M_{\mathrm{He}}}= \frac{0.25132}{4.002602}=0.06279\;\text{mol}
\]

---

### 2.  Absolute temperature  

\[
T = 500^{\circ}\text{C}=500+273.15=773.15\;\text{K}
\]

---

### 3.  Volume of the container  

\[
V = 20.000\;\text{dm}^{3}=20.000\;\text{L}=20.000\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^{3}=0.020000\;\text{m}^{3}
\]

---

### 4.  Pressure from the manometer  

Height of water column  

\[
h = 206.402\;\text{cm}=2.06402\;\text{m}
\]

Density of water at \(25^{\circ}\text{C}\)  

\[
\rho =0.99707\;\text{g cm}^{-3}=997.07\;\text{kg m}^{-3}
\]

\[
p = \rho g h = (997.07\;\text{kg m}^{-3})(9.80665\;\text{m s}^{-2})(2.06402\;\text{m})
      = 2.0182\times10^{4}\;\text{Pa}
\]

---

### 5.  Calculate \(R\)

\[
pV = (2.0182\times10^{4}\;\text{Pa})(0.020000\;\text{m}^{3}) = 4.0364\times10^{2}\;\text{J}
\]

\[
nT = (0.06279\;\text{mol})(773.15\;\text{K}) = 4.8546\times10^{1}\;\text{mol·K}
\]

\[
R = \frac{pV}{nT}= \frac{4.0364\times10^{2}}{4.8546\times10^{1}}
   = 8.314\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{8.314}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: A perfect gas undergoes isothermal compression, which reduces its volume by $2.20 \mathrm{dm}^3$. The final pressure and volume of the gas are $5.04 \mathrm{bar}$ and $4.65 \mathrm{dm}^3$, respectively. Calculate the original pressure of the gas in atm.
llm_output:
For an isothermal change of a perfect gas  

\[
p_1V_1=p_2V_2 .
\]

---

### 1.  Determine the initial volume  

The volume is reduced by \(2.20\;\text{dm}^{3}\):

\[
V_1 = V_2 + 2.20\;\text{dm}^{3}=4.65\;\text{dm}^{3}+2.20\;\text{dm}^{3}=6.85\;\text{dm}^{3}.
\]

---

### 2.  Find the initial pressure in the same units as the final pressure  

\[
p_1 = p_2\frac{V_2}{V_1}
     = 5.04\;\text{bar}\times\frac{4.65}{6.85}
     = 5.04\;\text{bar}\times0.679562
     = 3.425\;\text{bar}.
\]

---

### 3.  Convert the pressure to atmospheres  

\[
1\;\text{atm}=1.01325\;\text{bar}\\Longrightarrow\quad
p_1(\text{atm})=\frac{3.425\;\text{bar}}{1.01325\;\text{bar/atm}}
               =3.38\;\text{atm}.
\]

---

\[
\boxed{3.38}\ \text{atm}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an isothermal irreversible expansion against $p_{\mathrm{ex}}=0$.
llm_output:
The entropy change of the gas depends only on the initial and final states, so we can evaluate it with a reversible isothermal path:

\[
\Delta S = nR\ln\frac{V_2}{V_1}
\]

The volume doubles, thus \(V_2/V_1 = 2\).

Moles of nitrogen:

\[
n = \frac{m}{M_{\mathrm{N_2}}}= \frac{14\ \text{g}}{28.02\ \text{g mol}^{-1}} \approx 0.500\ \text{mol}
\]

Now

\[
\Delta S = (0.500\ \text{mol})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})\ln 2
          = 0.500 \times 8.314 \times 0.6931
          \approx 2.88\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

Since the expansion is against \(p_{\text{ex}}=0\) (free expansion), no heat is exchanged with the surroundings, so \(\Delta S_{\text{surroundings}} = 0\). The total entropy change of the universe equals the system’s change.

\[
\boxed{2.88}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in the molar Gibbs energy of hydrogen gas when its pressure is increased isothermally from $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$ to 100.0 atm at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.

A perfect gas undergoes isothermal compression, which reduces its volume by $2.20 \mathrm{dm}^3$. The final pressure and volume of the gas are $5.04 \mathrm{bar}$ and $4.65 \mathrm{dm}^3$, respectively. Calculate the original pressure of the gas in bar.

Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When $229 \mathrm{~J}$ of energy is supplied as heat to $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Ar}(\mathrm{g})$ at constant pressure, the temperature of the sample increases by $2.55 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the molar heat capacities at constant pressure of the gas.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The change in the Gibbs energy of a certain constant-pressure process was found to fit the expression $\Delta G / \text{J}=-85.40+36.5(T / \text{K})$. Calculate the value of $\Delta S$ for the process.
llm_output:
The temperature derivative of the Gibbs‑energy change at constant pressure gives the entropy change:

\[
\Delta S = -\left(\frac{\partial \Delta G}{\partial T}\right)_P .
\]

From the given expression  

\[
\Delta G = -85.40 + 36.5\,T\;(\text{J}),
\]

\[
\frac{\partial \Delta G}{\partial T}=36.5\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta S = -36.5\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-36.5}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A chemical reaction takes place in a container of cross-sectional area $100 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. As a result of the reaction, a piston is pushed out through $10 \mathrm{~cm}$ against an external pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$. Calculate the work done by the system.
llm_output:
The work done by the system is the external pressure multiplied by the change in volume:

\[
w = P_{\text{ext}}\;\Delta V
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Area}&=100\;\text{cm}^2 = 100\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^2 = 0.010\;\text{m}^2,\\[4pt]
\text{Displacement}&=10\;\text{cm}=0.10\;\text{m},\\[4pt]
\Delta V &= A\; \Delta x = 0.010\;\text{m}^2 \times 0.10\;\text{m}=1.0\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^3,\\[4pt]
P_{\text{ext}} &=1.0\;\text{atm}=1.0\times101325\;\text{Pa}=1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
w = (1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa})(1.0\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^3)=1.01325\times10^{2}\;\text{J}\approx 1.01\times10^{2}\;\text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{101.3}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The standard enthalpy of decomposition of the yellow complex $\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{NSO}_2$ into $\mathrm{NH}_3$ and $\mathrm{SO}_2$ is $+40 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard enthalpy of formation of $\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{NSO}_2$.
llm_output:
The decomposition reaction is  

\[
\mathrm{H_3NSO_2(g)} \;\longrightarrow\; \mathrm{NH_3(g)}+\mathrm{SO_2(g)}\qquad 
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{rxn}} = +40\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Using Hess’s law  

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{rxn}} = \sum \Delta_f H^\circ(\text{products})-
\sum \Delta_f H^\circ(\text{reactants})
\]

\[
+40 = \big[\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{NH_3})+\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{SO_2})\big]
      -\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{H_3NSO_2})
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{H_3NSO_2})=
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{NH_3})+\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{SO_2})-40
\]

Standard enthalpies of formation (298 K):  

\[
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{NH_3(g)}) = -46.1\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\qquad
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{SO_2(g)}) = -296.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{H_3NSO_2}) = (-46.1) + (-296.8) - 40
                                    = -382.9\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{-383}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The standard enthalpy of formation of ethylbenzene is $-12.5 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate its standard enthalpy of combustion.
llm_output:
The combustion reaction of ethylbenzene is  

\[
\mathrm{C_8H_{10}(l) + 10.5\,O_2(g) \rightarrow 8\,CO_2(g) + 5\,H_2O(l)}
\]

The standard enthalpy change is  

\[
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}}=
\Big[8\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2})+5\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O})\Big]
-\Big[\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{C_8H_{10}})+10.5\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{O_2})\Big]
\]

Using  

\[
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{CO_2(g)})=-393.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\qquad
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{H_2O(l)})=-285.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},
\]
\[
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{C_8H_{10}})=-12.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\qquad
\Delta_f H^\circ(\mathrm{O_2(g)})=0,
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H^\circ_{\text{comb}} &=
\big[8(-393.5)+5(-285.8)\big]-\big[-12.5+0\big] \\
&= \big[-3148.0-1429.0\big] + 12.5 \\
&= -4564.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\approx -4565\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{-4565}\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the work needed for a $65 \mathrm{~kg}$ person to climb through $4.0 \mathrm{~m}$ on the surface of the Earth.
llm_output:
The work required to raise a mass \(m\) through a height \(h\) against gravity is  

\[
W = mgh
\]

where \(g = 9.80665\ \text{m s}^{-2}\) (standard acceleration due to gravity).

\[
\begin{aligned}
W &= (65\ \text{kg})(9.80665\ \text{m s}^{-2})(4.0\ \text{m}) \\
  &= 2.55\times10^{3}\ \text{J}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.55\times10^{3}}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta S_\text{tot}$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_output:
The two blocks have equal heat capacities  

\[
C = m\,c = (10.0\;\text{kg})(10^{3}\,\text{g kg}^{-1})(0.385\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{g}^{-1})
      = 3.85\times10^{3}\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\]

Because the heat capacities are the same, the equilibrium temperature is the average:

\[
T_f=\frac{T_{\text{hot}}+T_{\text{cold}}}{2}
    =\frac{373.15\;\text{K}+273.15\;\text{K}}{2}=323.15\;\text{K}.
\]

The entropy change of each block is  

\[
\Delta S = C\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f}{T_i}\right).
\]

Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta S_{\text{tot}}&=C\Bigl[\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f}{T_{\text{hot}}}\right)
                     +\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f}{T_{\text{cold}}}\right)\Bigr]  \\
&=C\ln\!\left(\frac{T_f^{2}}{T_{\text{hot}}\,T_{\text{cold}}}\right)   \\
&=3.85\times10^{3}\;
   \ln\!\left(\frac{(323.15)^2}{(373.15)(273.15)}\right)                \\
&=3.85\times10^{3}\;(0.02422)                                            \\
&\approx 9.33\times10^{1}\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{93.3}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the work needed for a $65 \mathrm{~kg}$ person to climb through $4.0 \mathrm{~m}$ on the surface of the Moon $\left(g=1.60 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\right)$.
llm_output:
The mechanical work required to raise a mass \(m\) through a height \(h\) against a gravitational acceleration \(g\) is  

\[
W = mgh .
\]

Substituting the given values:

\[
\begin{aligned}
W &= (65\ \text{kg})(1.60\ \text{m s}^{-2})(4.0\ \text{m}) \\
  &= 65 \times 1.60 \times 4.0\ \text{J} \\
  &= 416\ \text{J}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{416}\ \text{J}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the final pressure of a sample of carbon dioxide that expands reversibly and adiabatically from $57.4 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to a final volume of $2.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$. Take $\gamma=1.4$.
llm_output:
For a reversible adiabatic change of an ideal gas  

\[
P V^{\gamma}= \text{constant}
\]

Hence  

\[
P_{2}=P_{1}\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma}
\]

Given  

\[
P_{1}=57.4\;\text{kPa},\qquad V_{1}=1.0\;\text{dm}^{3},\qquad 
\left(\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)=\frac{1.0}{2.0}=0.5,\qquad \gamma =1.4
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
P_{2}&=57.4\;\text{kPa}\;(0.5)^{1.4}\\
     &=57.4\;\text{kPa}\;\exp\!\bigl[1.4\ln(0.5)\bigr]\\
     &=57.4\;\text{kPa}\;\exp(-0.9704)\\
     &=57.4\;\text{kPa}\;(0.3789)\\
     &\approx 21.7\;\text{kPa}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{21.7}\ \text{kPa}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The fugacity coefficient of a certain gas at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ and 50 bar is 0.72. Calculate the difference of its molar Gibbs energy from that of a perfect gas in the same state.
llm_output:
The molar Gibbs‑energy deviation of a real gas from the ideal‑gas value is  

\[
\Delta \bar G = RT\ln\phi .
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
R &= 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\qquad 
T = 200\;\text{K},\\[4pt]
RT &= 8.314\times 200 = 1.6629\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}=1.6629\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\phi &=0.72,\qquad \ln\phi = \ln 0.72 = -0.3285 .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta \bar G = (1.6629\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1})(-0.3285)= -0.5465\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{-0.547}\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $q$.
llm_output:
For a reversible adiabatic (isentropic) process the definition of an adiabatic change is that no heat is exchanged with the surroundings:

\[
q_{\text{rev, ad}} = 0 .
\]

Hence, regardless of the change in temperature or the amount of work done, the heat transferred to the gas is

\[
\boxed{0}\ \text{J}.
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When $229 \mathrm{~J}$ of energy is supplied as heat to $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Ar}(\mathrm{g})$ at constant pressure, the temperature of the sample increases by $2.55 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the molar heat capacities at constant volume.
llm_output:
The heat supplied at constant pressure is related to the molar heat capacity at constant pressure by  

\[
q = n\,C_{p,m}\,\Delta T \;\Longrightarrow\; 
C_{p,m}= \frac{q}{n\Delta T}
      = \frac{229\ \text{J}}{(3.0\ \text{mol})(2.55\ \text{K})}
      = \frac{229}{7.65}\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
      \approx 29.9\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

For an ideal gas  

\[
C_{p,m}-C_{v,m}=R,
\]

where \(R = 8.314\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\). Hence  

\[
C_{v,m}=C_{p,m}-R \approx 29.9\;-\;8.314\;=\;21.6\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{21.6}\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. For the reaction $\mathrm{C}_2 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}(\mathrm{l})+3 \mathrm{O}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})+3 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{g})$, $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} U^\ominus=-1373 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$, calculate $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} H^{\ominus}$.
llm_output:
For an ideal‑gas reaction  

\[
\Delta H^{\ominus}= \Delta U^{\ominus}+ \Delta n_{\text{gas}}\,RT
\]

where \(\Delta n_{\text{gas}}\) is the change in the number of moles of gas.

**Reaction:**  

\[
\mathrm{C_2H_5OH(l)}+3\;\mathrm{O_2(g)}\rightarrow 2\;\mathrm{CO_2(g)}+3\;\mathrm{H_2O(g)}
\]

Gaseous reactants: \(3\;\text{mol}\) (O₂)  
Gaseous products: \(2+3 = 5\;\text{mol}\) (CO₂ + H₂O)  

\[
\Delta n_{\text{gas}} = 5-3 = +2
\]

Using \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(T = 298\;\text{K}\):

\[
\Delta n_{\text{gas}}RT = 2 \times 8.314 \times 298\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
                     = 4.955\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
                     = 4.96\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Given \(\Delta_{\mathrm r}U^{\ominus}= -1373\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\),

\[
\Delta_{\mathrm r}H^{\ominus}= -1373\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}+4.96\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
                           \approx -1368\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-1368}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $w$.
llm_output:
The process occurs at a constant volume (the container volume is fixed at \(15.0\;\text{dm}^{3}\)).  
For a closed system the only mechanical work is the pressure‑volume work  

\[
w = -\int_{V_i}^{V_f} P\,dV .
\]

Since \(V_i = V_f\), the integral vanishes:

\[
w = 0 .
\]

\[
\boxed{0}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $\Delta H$.
llm_output:
The heat supplied at constant volume equals the change in internal energy  

\[
q_{V}= \Delta U = 2.35\ \text{kJ}
\]

For the enthalpy change we use  

\[
\Delta H = \Delta U + \Delta (PV)=\Delta U + V\Delta P
\]

The pressure of the non‑ideal CO₂ gas is obtained from the van der Waals equation  

\[
\bigl(P+\frac{a n^{2}}{V^{2}}\bigr)(V-nb)=nRT
\]

with  

\[
n = 2.0\ \text{mol},\qquad V = 15.0\ \text{dm}^{3}=0.015\ \text{m}^{3},
\]
\[
a = 3.592\ \text{L}^{2}\,\text{bar mol}^{-2}=0.3592\ \text{Pa·m}^{6}\,\text{mol}^{-2},
\qquad 
b = 0.04267\ \text{L mol}^{-1}=4.267\times10^{-5}\ \text{m}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1},
\]
\[
R = 8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\]

---

### Initial pressure ( \(T_1 = 300\ \text{K}\) )

\[
P_i = \frac{nRT_1}{V-nb}-\frac{a n^{2}}{V^{2}}
     =\frac{2(8.314)(300)}{0.015-2b}-\frac{a(2)^{2}}{(0.015)^{2}}
     =3.28\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa}=3.24\ \text{bar}
\]

### Final pressure ( \(T_2 = 341\ \text{K}\) )

\[
P_f = \frac{nRT_2}{V-nb}-\frac{a n^{2}}{V^{2}}
     =\frac{2(8.314)(341)}{0.015-2b}-\frac{a(2)^{2}}{(0.015)^{2}}
     =3.74\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa}=3.74\ \text{bar}
\]

\[
\Delta P = P_f-P_i = 4.56\times10^{4}\ \text{Pa}
\]

---

### Enthalpy change

\[
V\Delta P = (0.015\ \text{m}^{3})(4.56\times10^{4}\ \text{Pa}) = 6.84\times10^{2}\ \text{J}=0.684\ \text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{\Delta H = q_{V}+V\Delta P = 2.35\ \text{kJ}+0.684\ \text{kJ}=3.03\ \text{kJ}}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_output:
The change in internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on the temperature change:

\[
\Delta U = n\,C_{V,m}\,\Delta T
\]

where  

\(n = 3.00\ \text{mol}\)  

\(C_{V,m}=27.5\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\)  

\(\Delta T = T_{2}-T_{1}=250\ \text{K}-200\ \text{K}=50\ \text{K}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta U &= (3.00\ \text{mol})(27.5\ \text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})(50\ \text{K})\\
         &= 4125\ \text{J}\\
         &= 4.125\ \text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

Rounded to appropriate significant figures:

\[
\boxed{4.13}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $q$.
llm_output:
The expansion is specified to be **adiabatic**, meaning that no heat is transferred between the system and its surroundings. Therefore, the heat exchanged by the gas during the process is

\[
\boxed{0\ \text{J}}
\]

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the molar volume.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta S$.
llm_output:
For a reversible adiabatic (isentropic) process the entropy change of the system is zero:

\[
\Delta S_{\text{system}} = 0
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{0}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_output:
The work done on the gas during the irreversible expansion is  

\[
w = -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V,
\qquad 
\Delta V = A\,\Delta x .
\]

The piston cross‑sectional area  

\[
A = 10.0\;\text{cm}^2 = 10.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^2 = 1.0\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^2 ,
\]

and the displacement  

\[
\Delta x = 20\;\text{cm}=0.20\;\text{m},
\]

so  

\[
\Delta V = (1.0\times10^{-3}\,\text{m}^2)(0.20\,\text{m}) = 2.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^3 .
\]

With the external pressure \(P_{\text{ext}} = 1.0\;\text{atm}=1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}\),

\[
w = - (1.01325\times10^{5}\,\text{Pa})(2.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{m}^3)
   = -2.03\times10^{1}\,\text{J}
   = -20.3\;\text{J}.
\]

Because the process is adiabatic (\(q=0\)), the change in internal energy equals the work:

\[
\Delta U = q + w = w = -20.3\;\text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-20.3}\ \text{J}
\]

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the virial expansion of the van der Waals equation.
llm_output:
The virial form of the van der Waals equation gives the second virial coefficient  

\[
B(T)=b-\frac{a}{RT},
\]

so that the compression factor (virial expansion in pressure) is  

\[
Z = 1+\frac{B(T)\,p}{RT}=1+\left(b-\frac{a}{RT}\right)\frac{p}{RT}.
\]

Using the data (with \(R=0.082057\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{atm}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1}\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
RT &=0.082057\times 776.4=63.718\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{atm}\,\text{mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\frac{a}{RT}&=\frac{5.464}{63.718}=0.08578\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
B(T)&=b-\frac{a}{RT}=0.03049-0.08578=-0.05529\;\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\frac{p}{RT}&=\frac{327.6}{63.718}=5.1385,\\[4pt]
Z&=1+B(T)\frac{p}{RT}=1-0.05529\times5.1385=0.716.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{Z\approx 0.72}
\]

question: A sample of $255 \mathrm{mg}$ of neon occupies $3.00 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $122 \mathrm{K}$. Use the perfect gas law to calculate the pressure of the gas.
llm_output:
The ideal‑gas equation is  

\[
PV=nRT
\]

---

**1. Convert the given data to SI‑compatible units**

* Mass of neon:  

\[
m = 255\;\text{mg}=0.255\;\text{g}
\]

* Molar mass of neon (Ne):  

\[
M_{\text{Ne}} = 20.18\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

* Volume:  

\[
V = 3.00\;\text{dm}^{3}=3.00\;\text{L}
\]

* Temperature:  

\[
T = 122\;\text{K}
\]

* Gas constant (in L·atm·K\(^{-1}\)·mol\(^{-1}\)):  

\[
R = 0.082057\;\text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{·mol}^{-1}
\]

---

**2. Calculate the amount of substance (moles)**  

\[
n=\frac{m}{M_{\text{Ne}}}= \frac{0.255\;\text{g}}{20.18\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}
      = 1.26\times 10^{-2}\;\text{mol}
\]

---

**3. Solve for the pressure**

\[
P=\frac{nRT}{V}
   =\frac{(1.26\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol})(0.082057\;\text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{·mol}^{-1})(122\;\text{K})}
          {3.00\;\text{L}}
\]

\[
P = \frac{0.1265\;\text{L·atm}}{3.00\;\text{L}}
   = 4.22\times10^{-2}\;\text{atm}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{0.0422}\ \text{atm}
\]

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the data.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta H$.
llm_output:
The enthalpy change for an ideal gas depends only on temperature:

\[
\Delta H = n C_{p,m}\,\Delta T
\]

For a diatomic gas  

\[
C_{p,m}=C_{V,m}+R = 27.5\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}+8.314\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
           = 35.8\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\Delta T = 250\;\text{K}-200\;\text{K}=50\;\text{K}
\]

\[
\Delta H = (3.00\;\text{mol})(35.8\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})(50\;\text{K})
          = 5.37\times10^{3}\;\text{J}=5.37\;\text{kJ}
\]

\[
\boxed{5.37}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: A certain gas obeys the van der Waals equation with $a=0.50 \mathrm{~m}^6 \mathrm{~Pa}$ $\mathrm{mol}^{-2}$. Its volume is found to be $5.00 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $273 \mathrm{~K}$ and $3.0 \mathrm{MPa}$. From this information calculate the van der Waals constant $b$. What is the compression factor for this gas at the prevailing temperature and pressure?
Use the van der Waals parameters for chlorine to calculate approximate values of the Boyle temperature of chlorine.
llm_output:
The Boyle temperature is obtained from the condition that the second virial coefficient vanishes:

\[
B(T)=b-\frac{a}{RT}=0\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
T_{\text{B}}=\frac{a}{Rb}
\]

For chlorine the van‑der‑Waals constants are  

\[
a = 6.49\;\text{L}^{2}\,\text{bar}\,\text{mol}^{-2},\qquad 
b = 0.0562\;\text{L}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

Using the gas constant in the same units, \(R = 0.08314\;\text{L·bar·K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\),

\[
T_{\text{B}}=\frac{6.49}{(0.08314)(0.0562)}
          =\frac{6.49}{0.004672}\approx 1.39\times10^{3}\ \text{K}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.39\times10^{3}}\ \text{K}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta S$.
llm_output:
The entropy change of the gas depends only on the initial and final equilibrium states, so we may evaluate it along any convenient reversible path.  
For an ideal gas  

\[
\Delta S = nC_{V,m}\ln\!\frac{T_f}{T_i}+nR\ln\!\frac{V_f}{V_i}.
\]

---

### 1.  Initial state  

\[
n = 2.0\;\text{mol},\qquad T_i = 298.15\;\text{K},\qquad 
P_i = 10\;\text{atm}.
\]

\[
V_i = \frac{nRT_i}{P_i}
      =\frac{(2.0)(0.082057\;\text{L·atm·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1})(298.15\;\text{K})}
            {10\;\text{atm}}
      \approx 4.89\;\text{L}.
\]

---

### 2.  Final state (adiabatic irreversible expansion)

The piston moves \( \Delta x = 20\;\text{cm}=0.20\;\text{m}\) in a cylinder of cross‑section  

\[
A = 10.0\;\text{cm}^2 = 1.0\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^2,
\]

so the volume increase is  

\[
\Delta V = A\Delta x = 1.0\times10^{-3}\times0.20 = 2.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^3
          =0.20\;\text{L}.
\]

Work done on the gas (adiabatic, \(q=0\))  

\[
\Delta U = w = -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V
          =-(1.0\;\text{atm})(0.20\;\text{L})
          =-20.3\;\text{J}.
\]

With \(C_{V,m}=28.8\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\),

\[
\Delta T = \frac{\Delta U}{nC_{V,m}}
          =\frac{-20.3}{2.0\times28.8}
          \approx -0.35\;\text{K},
\qquad
T_f = T_i+\Delta T \approx 297.8\;\text{K}.
\]

Hence  

\[
V_f = V_i + \Delta V \approx 4.89\;\text{L}+0.20\;\text{L}=5.09\;\text{L}.
\]

---

### 3.  Entropy change

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta S &= nC_{V,m}\ln\!\frac{T_f}{T_i}+nR\ln\!\frac{V_f}{V_i}\\[4pt]
         &= (2.0)(28.8)\,\ln\!\frac{297.8}{298.15}
            +(2.0)(8.314)\,\ln\!\frac{5.09}{4.89}\\[4pt]
         &\approx 57.6(-0.00117)+16.628(0.0401)\\[4pt]
         &\approx -0.067 + 0.667\\[4pt]
         &\approx 0.60\;\text{J K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.60}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_output:
The heating occurs at constant volume, so the only contribution to the change in internal energy is the temperature‑dependent part.  
For a real gas described by the van der Waals equation the residual internal‑energy term is  

\[
U^{\text{res}}=-\frac{a n^{2}}{V},
\]

which is independent of temperature.  Because the volume is fixed, this term does not change during the process, i.e. \(\Delta U^{\text{res}}=0\).

Hence  

\[
\Delta U = n\,C_{V,m}\,\Delta T .
\]

Using the molar heat capacity of CO\(_2\) at constant volume (\(C_{V,m}\approx 28.5\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\)):

\[
\Delta T = 341\;\text{K} - 300\;\text{K}=41\;\text{K},
\]

\[
\Delta U = 2.0\;\text{mol}\times 28.5\;\frac{\text{J}}{\text{mol·K}}\times 41\;\text{K}
          \approx 2.35\times10^{3}\;\text{J}=2.35\;\text{kJ}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.35}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: The change in molar internal energy when $\mathrm{CaCO}_3(\mathrm{~s})$ as calcite converts to another form, aragonite, is $+0.21 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the difference between the molar enthalpy and internal energy changes when the pressure is 1.0 bar given that the densities of the polymorphs are $2.71 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and $2.93 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$, respectively.
llm_output:
The difference between the molar enthalpy change \(\Delta H\) and the internal‑energy change \(\Delta U\) at constant pressure is  

\[
\Delta H-\Delta U = \Delta(PV)=P\;\Delta V .
\]

The molar volume of each polymorph is obtained from the molar mass of \(\mathrm{CaCO_3}\) \((M=100.09\;\text{g mol}^{-1})\) and the given densities:

\[
V_{\text{calcite}}=\frac{M}{\rho_{\text{calcite}}}
   =\frac{100.09\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{2.71\;\text{g cm}^{-3}}
   =36.95\;\text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1},
\]

\[
V_{\text{aragonite}}=\frac{M}{\rho_{\text{aragonite}}}
   =\frac{100.09\;\text{g mol}^{-1}}{2.93\;\text{g cm}^{-3}}
   =34.15\;\text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta V = V_{\text{aragonite}}-V_{\text{calcite}}
         = -2.80\;\text{cm}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}
         = -2.80\times10^{-6}\;\text{m}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

At \(P = 1.0\;\text{bar}=1.0\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}\),

\[
\Delta(PV)=P\,\Delta V
          =(1.0\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa})(-2.80\times10^{-6}\;\text{m}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1})
          =-0.28\;\text{Pa}\,\text{m}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Thus  

\[
\boxed{-0.28}\ \text{Pa m}^{3}\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta T$.

A container is divided into two equal compartments. One contains $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$; the other contains $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the Gibbs energy of mixing when the partition is removed. Assume perfect behaviour.
llm_output:
The Gibbs energy change for mixing ideal gases at constant \(T\) and \(P\) is  

\[
\Delta G_{\text{mix}} = nRT\sum_i x_i\ln x_i ,
\]

where  

\[
n = n_{\mathrm{H_2}}+n_{\mathrm{N_2}} = 3.0+1.0 = 4.0\ \text{mol},
\qquad
x_{\mathrm{H_2}}=\frac{3}{4}=0.75,\qquad
x_{\mathrm{N_2}}=\frac{1}{4}=0.25,
\]
\[
R = 8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\qquad
T = 25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}=298\ \text{K}.
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sum_i x_i\ln x_i &=
0.75\ln(0.75)+0.25\ln(0.25)\\
&=0.75(-0.28768)+0.25(-1.38629)\\
&=-0.21576-0.34657\\
&=-0.56233 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta G_{\text{mix}} = (4.0)(8.314)(298)(-0.56233)
          = -5.57\times10^{3}\ \text{J}
          = -5.6\ \text{kJ}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-5.6}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: Suppose the concentration of a solute decays exponentially along the length of a container. Calculate the thermodynamic force on the solute at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ given that the concentration falls to half its value in $10 \mathrm{~cm}$.
llm_output:
The concentration profile is exponential  

\[
c(x)=c_{0}\,e^{-kx},
\qquad 
c(10\;\text{cm})=\frac{c_{0}}{2}
\]

so  

\[
e^{-k(10\;\text{cm})}= \frac12\;\Longrightarrow\;
k=\frac{\ln 2}{10\;\text{cm}}
      =\frac{\ln 2}{0.10\;\text{m}}
      =6.931\,\text{m}^{-1}.
\]

For an ideal dilute solution the chemical potential is  

\[
\mu =\mu^{\circ}+RT\ln c,
\]

hence the thermodynamic force per mole is  

\[
F = -\frac{\partial\mu}{\partial x}
    =-RT\frac{\partial\ln c}{\partial x}
    =RT\,k .
\]

At \(T=25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}=298\;\text{K}\),

\[
RT = (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298\;\text{K})
     = 2.48\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}.
\]

Therefore  

\[
F = (2.48\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1})(6.931\;\text{m}^{-1})
    \approx 1.72\times10^{4}\;\text{N mol}^{-1}
    = 17.2\;\text{kN mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{17.2}\ \text{kN mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Calculate the typical wavelength of neutrons that have reached thermal equilibrium with their surroundings at $373 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_output:
The thermal de Broglie wavelength of a neutron at temperature \(T\) can be estimated from  

\[
\lambda=\frac{h}{\sqrt{2m_{\text n}k_{\text B}T}},
\]

where  

\[
h = 6.62607015\times10^{-34}\;\text{J·s},\qquad 
k_{\text B}=1.380649\times10^{-23}\;\text{J·K}^{-1},\qquad 
m_{\text n}=1.6749275\times10^{-27}\;\text{kg},
\]

and \(T = 373\;\text{K}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
k_{\text B}T &= 1.380649\times10^{-23}\times 373
               = 5.152\times10^{-21}\;\text{J},\\[4pt]
2m_{\text n}k_{\text B}T &= 2(1.6749275\times10^{-27})(5.152\times10^{-21})
                         = 1.726\times10^{-47}\;\text{kg·J},\\[4pt]
\sqrt{2m_{\text n}k_{\text B}T} &= \sqrt{1.726\times10^{-47}}
                                 = 4.16\times10^{-24}\;\text{kg·m·s}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\lambda &= \frac{6.62607015\times10^{-34}}{4.16\times10^{-24}}
          = 1.60\times10^{-10}\;\text{m}
          = 1.60\times10^{2}\;\text{pm}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.6\times10^{2}}\ \text{pm}
\]

question: Calculate the separation of the $\{123\}$ planes of an orthorhombic unit cell with $a=0.82 \mathrm{~nm}, b=0.94 \mathrm{~nm}$, and $c=0.75 \mathrm{~nm}$.
llm_output:
The interplanar spacing for an orthorhombic crystal is  

\[
\frac{1}{d_{hkl}^{2}}=\frac{h^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{k^{2}}{b^{2}}+\frac{l^{2}}{c^{2}} .
\]

For the \(\{123\}\) planes \((h,k,l)=(1,2,3)\) and  

\[
a=0.82\;\text{nm},\qquad b=0.94\;\text{nm},\qquad c=0.75\;\text{nm},
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{d^{2}} &=\frac{1^{2}}{0.82^{2}}+\frac{2^{2}}{0.94^{2}}+\frac{3^{2}}{0.75^{2}}  \\
&= \frac{1}{0.6724}+ \frac{4}{0.8836}+ \frac{9}{0.5625} \\
&\approx 1.487+4.527+16.000 = 22.014\;\text{nm}^{-2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
d = \frac{1}{\sqrt{22.014}}\;\text{nm}\approx 0.213\;\text{nm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.213}\ \text{nm}
\]

question: Caesium (m.p. $29^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, b.p. $686^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) was introduced into a container and heated to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. When a hole of diameter $0.50 \mathrm{~mm}$ was opened in the container for $100 \mathrm{~s}$, a mass loss of $385 \mathrm{mg}$ was measured. Calculate the vapour pressure of liquid caesium at $500 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_output:
The mass‑loss rate through a small hole in the molecular‑flow regime is  

\[
\frac{dm}{dt}= \frac{PA}{\sqrt{2\pi RT/M}},
\]

so that  

\[
P=\frac{dm/dt}{A}\sqrt{2\pi RT/M}.
\]

---

**Data**

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta m &=385\;\text{mg}=3.85\times10^{-4}\;\text{g}=3.85\times10^{-7}\;\text{kg},\\[2pt]
\Delta t &=100\;\text{s}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\; \frac{dm}{dt}=3.85\times10^{-9}\;\text{kg s}^{-1},\\[2pt]
d &=0.50\;\text{mm}=5.0\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}\;\Longrightarrow\; 
A=\frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}=1.96\times10^{-7}\;\text{m}^{2},\\[2pt]
T &=500\;\text{K},\qquad 
M_{\text{Cs}} =132.905\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=1.32905\times10^{-1}\;\text{kg mol}^{-1},\\[2pt]
R &=8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

**Calculation**

\[
\sqrt{\frac{2\pi RT}{M}}=
\sqrt{\frac{2\pi(8.314)(500)}{0.132905}}
\approx 4.44\times10^{2}\;\text{kg}^{1/2}\,\text{m}^{-1/2}\,\text{s}^{-1}.
\]

\[
P=\frac{3.85\times10^{-9}\;\text{kg s}^{-1}}{1.96\times10^{-7}\;\text{m}^{2}}
\;\times\;4.44\times10^{2}
\approx 8.7\times10^{3}\;\text{Pa}=8.7\;\text{kPa}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.7}\ \text{kPa}
\]

question: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength for an electron with a kinetic energy of $100 \mathrm{eV}$
llm_output:
The de Broglie wavelength is  

\[
\lambda=\frac{h}{p}=\frac{h}{\sqrt{2m_eK}}
\]

with  

\[
h = 6.62607015\times10^{-34}\ \text{J·s},\qquad 
m_e = 9.10938356\times10^{-31}\ \text{kg},\qquad 
K = 100\ \text{eV}=100\times1.602176634\times10^{-19}\ \text{J}=1.602176634\times10^{-17}\ \text{J}.
\]

\[
p=\sqrt{2m_eK}
   =\sqrt{2(9.10938356\times10^{-31})(1.602176634\times10^{-17})}
   \approx 5.40\times10^{-24}\ \text{kg·m·s}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\lambda=\frac{6.62607015\times10^{-34}}{5.40\times10^{-24}}
        \approx 1.23\times10^{-10}\ \text{m}
        =0.123\ \text{nm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.123}\ \text{nm}
\]

question: A helium-neon laser (used in supermarket scanners) emits light at $632.8 \mathrm{~nm}$. Calculate the frequency of this light.
llm_output:
The frequency \(\nu\) of light is related to its wavelength \(\lambda\) by  

\[
\nu=\frac{c}{\lambda},
\]

where \(c = 3.00\times10^{8}\ \text{m s}^{-1}\) and \(\lambda = 632.8\ \text{nm}=632.8\times10^{-9}\ \text{m}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
\nu &= \frac{3.00\times10^{8}\ \text{m s}^{-1}}{632.8\times10^{-9}\ \text{m}}  \\
    &= \frac{3.00}{6.328}\times10^{8+7}\ \text{s}^{-1} \\
    &= 0.4745\times10^{15}\ \text{s}^{-1} \\
    &= 4.745\times10^{14}\ \text{Hz}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Expressed in units of \(10^{14}\,\text{Hz}\),

\[
\boxed{4.75}\times10^{14}\,\text{Hz}.
\]

question: Calculate the wavelength and the energy of a photon associated with the series limit of the Lyman series.

The data below show the temperature variation of the equilibrium constant of the reaction $\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3(\mathrm{~s}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s})+\mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$. Calculate the standard reaction enthalpy of the decomposition.
$\begin{array}{lllll}T / \mathrm{K} & 350 & 400 & 450 & 500 \\ K & 3.98 \times 10^{-4} & 1.41 \times 10^{-2} & 1.86 \times 10^{-1} & 1.48\end{array}$
llm_output:
The van’t Hoff equation  

\[
\ln K =-\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\frac{1}{T}+ \frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}
\]

shows that a plot of \(\ln K\) versus \(1/T\) is linear with slope \(-\Delta H^{\circ}/R\).

\[
\begin{array}{c|c|c}
T\ (\mathrm{K}) & K & \ln K \\ \hline
350 & 3.98\times10^{-4} & -7.829 \\
400 & 1.41\times10^{-2} & -4.261 \\
450 & 1.86\times10^{-1} & -1.683 \\
500 & 1.48 & 0.392
\end{array}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
x &= \frac{1}{T}\;(\mathrm{K^{-1}}) &
y &= \ln K
\end{aligned}
\]

A linear regression of the four \((x,y)\) points gives  

\[
\text{slope}=m = -9.56\times10^{3}\ \mathrm{K}
\]

Since \(m = -\Delta H^{\circ}/R\),

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}= -mR = (9.56\times10^{3}\,\text{K})(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})
          = 7.95\times10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{79.5}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Calculate the reduced mass of a nitrogen molecule in which both nitrogen atoms have an atomic mass of 14.00.
llm_output:
The reduced mass \(\mu\) of a diatomic molecule with identical atoms of mass \(m\) is  

\[
\mu=\frac{m\cdot m}{m+m}=\frac{m^{2}}{2m}=\frac{m}{2}.
\]

For nitrogen atoms with an atomic mass of \(14.00\;\text{u}\),

\[
\mu=\frac{14.00\;\text{u}}{2}=7.00\;\text{u}.
\]

\[
\boxed{7.00}\ \text{u}
\]

question: Calculate the percentage difference between $\ln (1+x)$ and $x$ for $x=0.0050$
llm_output:
The percentage difference (relative error) between \(\ln(1+x)\) and the linear approximation \(x\) is  

\[
\text{Percent difference}= \frac{|\,\ln(1+x)-x\,|}{|\,\ln(1+x)\,|}\times 100\%
\]

For \(x = 0.0050\),

\[
\ln(1+0.0050)=\ln(1.005)=0.004987531\ldots
\]

\[
\Delta = \ln(1+x)-x = 0.004987531-0.005 = -1.2469\times10^{-5}
\]

\[
\text{Percent difference}= \frac{1.2469\times10^{-5}}{0.004987531}\times100\%
\approx 0.25\%
\]

\[
\boxed{0.25}\%
\]

question: Calculate the number of photons in a $2.00 \mathrm{~mJ}$ light pulse at (a) $1.06 \mu \mathrm{m}$

Calculate the energy associated with an $\alpha$ particle that has fallen through a potential difference of $4.0 \mathrm{~V}$. Take the mass of an $\alpha$ particle to be $6.64 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}$.
llm_output:
The energy gained by a charge \(q\) when it moves through a potential difference \(V\) is  

\[
E = qV .
\]

An \(\alpha\) particle carries a charge of \(+2e\), where \(e = 1.602\times10^{-19}\,\text{C}\). Thus  

\[
q = 2e = 2(1.602\times10^{-19}\,\text{C}) = 3.204\times10^{-19}\,\text{C}.
\]

With \(V = 4.0\ \text{V}\),

\[
E = (3.204\times10^{-19}\,\text{C})(4.0\ \text{V})
   = 1.2816\times10^{-18}\,\text{J}.
\]

Expressed in units of \(10^{-18}\,\text{J}\) per \(\alpha\)-particle, the numerical factor is  

\[
\boxed{1.28}\ \times10^{-18}\,\text{J/α‑particle}.
\]

question: In the infrared spectrum of $\mathrm{H}^{127} \mathrm{I}$, there is an intense line at $2309 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$. Calculate the force constant of $\mathrm{H}^{127} \mathrm{I}$.
llm_output:
The vibrational wavenumber \(\tilde\nu\) (in cm\(^{-1}\)) is related to the force constant \(k\) by  

\[
\tilde\nu=\frac{1}{2\pi c}\sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}}\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
k=(2\pi c\tilde\nu)^{2}\mu .
\]

* \(c = 2.9979\times10^{10}\ \text{cm s}^{-1}\)  
* \(\tilde\nu = 2309\ \text{cm}^{-1}\)  

\[
2\pi c\tilde\nu = 2\pi(2.9979\times10^{10})(2309)
                 \approx 4.35\times10^{14}\ \text{s}^{-1}.
\]

The reduced mass of \(\mathrm{H}^{127}\mathrm{I}\) is  

\[
\mu = \frac{m_{\mathrm H}\,m_{\mathrm I}}{m_{\mathrm H}+m_{\mathrm I}}
     \approx \frac{1.0078\times126.904}{1.0078+126.904}\,\text{u}
     \approx 0.9999\ \text{u}
     =0.9999(1.6605\times10^{-27})\ \text{kg}
     \approx 1.66\times10^{-27}\ \text{kg}.
\]

Hence  

\[
k = (4.35\times10^{14})^{2}\,(1.66\times10^{-27})
    \approx 3.14\times10^{2}\ \text{N m}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{3.14\times10^{2}}\ \text{N·m}^{-1}
\]

question: The force constant of ${ }^{35} \mathrm{Cl}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$ is $319 \mathrm{~N} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-1}$. Calculate the fundamental vibrational frequency
llm_output:
The vibrational wavenumber of a diatomic molecule is  

\[
\tilde{\nu}= \frac{1}{2\pi c}\sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}},
\]

where  

* \(k = 319\;\text{N\,m}^{-1}\) (force constant),  
* \(\mu\) is the reduced mass, and  
* \(c = 2.9979\times10^{10}\;\text{cm s}^{-1}\).

For \({}^{35}\mathrm{Cl}_2\) each chlorine atom has mass  

\[
m = 34.9689\;\text{u}=34.9689(1.66054\times10^{-27})\;\text{kg}=5.805\times10^{-26}\;\text{kg},
\]

so the reduced mass is  

\[
\mu = \frac{m}{2}=2.902\times10^{-26}\;\text{kg}.
\]

Now  

\[
\sqrt{\frac{k}{\mu}} = \sqrt{\frac{319}{2.902\times10^{-26}}}
                     = 1.05\times10^{14}\;\text{s}^{-1},
\]

\[
\tilde{\nu}= \frac{1}{2\pi(2.9979\times10^{10})}\,
             (1.05\times10^{14})
           = 5.57\times10^{2}\;\text{cm}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{5.57\times10^{2}}\ \text{cm}^{-1}
\]

question: Calculate the kinetic energy of an electron in a beam of electrons accelerated by a voltage increment of $100 \mathrm{~V}$

Example 5-3 shows that a Maclaurin expansion of a Morse potential leads to
$$
V(x)=D \beta^2 x^2+\cdots
$$
Given that $D=7.31 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{~J} \cdot$ molecule ${ }^{-1}$ and $\beta=1.81 \times 10^{10} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}$ for $\mathrm{HCl}$, calculate the force constant of $\mathrm{HCl}$.
Using the Bohr theory, calculate the ionization energy (in electron volts and in $\mathrm{kJ} \cdot \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ ) of singly ionized helium.
llm_output:
The ionization energy of He⁺ corresponds to the energy required to remove the electron from the \(n=1\) level to \(n=\infty\).

\[
E_n = -\frac{Z^{2}R_{\mathrm H}}{n^{2}},\qquad 
R_{\mathrm H}=13.6\ \text{eV},\; Z=2,\; n=1
\]

\[
E_{\text{ion}} = -E_{1}=Z^{2}R_{\mathrm H}=4\times13.6\ \text{eV}=54.4\ \text{eV}
\]

Converting to kilojoules per mole ( \(1\ \text{eV}=96.485\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\) ):

\[
54.4\ \text{eV}\times96.485\ \frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{mol·eV}}
=5.25\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{54.4}\ \text{eV}\;(\approx5.25\times10^{3}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1})
\]

question:
$$
\beta=2 \pi c \tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{obs}}\left(\frac{\mu}{2 D}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$
Given that $\tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{obs}}=2886 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ and $D=440.2 \mathrm{~kJ} \cdot \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ for $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$, calculate $\beta$.

To a good approximation, the microwave spectrum of $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$ consists of a series of equally spaced lines, separated by $6.26 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~Hz}$. Calculate the bond length of $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$.
llm_output:
The rotational levels of a rigid diatomic molecule are  

\[
E_J = hB\,J(J+1),\qquad 
\tilde\nu_{J\rightarrow J+1}=2B(J+1)
\]

so the spacing between successive microwave lines is  

\[
\Delta\nu = 2B .
\]

Given \(\Delta\nu = 6.26\times10^{11}\,\text{Hz}\),

\[
B = \frac{\Delta\nu}{2}=3.13\times10^{11}\ \text{Hz}.
\]

For a rigid rotor  

\[
B = \frac{h}{8\pi^{2}I},\qquad I=\mu r^{2},
\]

where \(\mu\) is the reduced mass and \(r\) the bond length.

---

### Reduced mass \(\mu\)

\[
\mu = \frac{m_{\mathrm H}\,m_{\mathrm{Cl}}}{m_{\mathrm H}+m_{\mathrm{Cl}}}
      =\frac{1.007825\,\text{u}\times34.968852\,\text{u}}
            {1.007825+34.968852\,\text{u}}
      =0.9795\ \text{u}
\]

\[
1\ \text{u}=1.6605390666\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg}
\Longrightarrow 
\mu =0.9795\times1.6605390666\times10^{-27}
     =1.63\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg}.
\]

---

### Moment of inertia \(I\)

\[
I = \frac{h}{8\pi^{2}B}
   =\frac{6.62607015\times10^{-34}\,\text{J·s}}
          {8\pi^{2}\,(3.13\times10^{11}\,\text{s}^{-1})}
   =2.68\times10^{-47}\ \text{kg·m}^{2}.
\]

---

### Bond length \(r\)

\[
r = \sqrt{\frac{I}{\mu}}
   =\sqrt{\frac{2.68\times10^{-47}}{1.63\times10^{-27}}}
   =\sqrt{1.65\times10^{-20}}
   =1.28\times10^{-10}\ \text{m}
   =128\ \text{pm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{128}\ \text{pm}
\]

question: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of an electron traveling at $1.00 \%$ of the speed of light.

It turns out that the solution of the Schrödinger equation for the Morse potential can be expressed as
$$
G(v)=\tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{e}}\left(v+\frac{1}{2}\right)-\tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{e}} \tilde{x}_{\mathrm{e}}\left(v+\frac{1}{2}\right)^2
$$
The Harmonic Oscillator and Vibrational Spectroscopy
where
$$
\tilde{x}_{\mathrm{e}}=\frac{h c \tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{e}}}{4 D}
$$
Given that $\tilde{\omega}_{\mathrm{e}}=2886 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}$ and $D=440.2 \mathrm{~kJ} \cdot \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$ for $\mathrm{H}^{35} \mathrm{Cl}$, calculate $\tilde{x}_{\mathrm{e}}$.
llm_output:
The anharmonicity constant is  

\[
\tilde{x}_{e}= \frac{h\,c\,\tilde{\omega}_{e}}{4D},
\]

where  

\[
h = 6.62607015\times10^{-34}\;\text{J·s},\qquad 
c = 2.99792458\times10^{10}\;\text{cm·s}^{-1},
\qquad 
\tilde{\omega}_{e}=2886\;\text{cm}^{-1},
\]
\[
D = 440.2\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}=4.402\times10^{5}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}.
\]

First convert the dissociation energy to a per‑molecule value  

\[
D_{\text{mol}}=\frac{4.402\times10^{5}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}}{N_{\!A}}
          =\frac{4.402\times10^{5}}{6.02214076\times10^{23}}
          =7.312\times10^{-19}\;\text{J}.
\]

Now evaluate the numerator  

\[
h c \tilde{\omega}_{e}= (6.62607015\times10^{-34})(2.99792458\times10^{10})(2886)
                      =5.733\times10^{-20}\;\text{J}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\tilde{x}_{e}= \frac{5.733\times10^{-20}}{4(7.312\times10^{-19})}
            =\frac{5.733\times10^{-20}}{2.925\times10^{-18}}
            =1.96\times10^{-2}.
\]

\[
\boxed{0.0196}
\]  

(The anharmonicity constant \(\tilde{x}_{e}\) is dimensionless.)

question: Calculate the probability that a particle in a one-dimensional box of length $a$ is found between 0 and $a / 2$.
llm_output:
The normalized wavefunction for the ground state of a particle in a one‑dimensional infinite well of length \(a\) is  

\[
\psi_{1}(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{a}}\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right),\qquad 0\le x\le a .
\]

The probability of finding the particle between \(x=0\) and \(x=a/2\) is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
P &=\int_{0}^{a/2}\!|\psi_{1}(x)|^{2}\,dx
   =\frac{2}{a}\int_{0}^{a/2}\sin^{2}\!\left(\frac{\pi x}{a}\right)dx \\[4pt]
  &=\frac{2}{a}\left[\frac{x}{2}-\frac{\sin\!\left(2\pi x/a\right)}{4\pi/a}\right]_{0}^{a/2}
   =\frac{2}{a}\left(\frac{a}{4}\right)=\frac12 .
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{\frac12}
\]

question: A chemical reaction takes place in a container of cross-sectional area $50 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. As a result of the reaction, a piston is pushed out through $15 \mathrm{~cm}$ against an external pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$. Calculate the work done by the system.
llm_output:
The work done by the system during the expansion against a constant external pressure is  

\[
w = -P_{\text{ext}}\Delta V .
\]

The volume change is  

\[
\Delta V = A\,\Delta x = (50\;\text{cm}^2)(15\;\text{cm})
          = (5.0\times10^{-3}\;\text{m}^2)(0.15\;\text{m})
          = 7.5\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^3 .
\]

The external pressure in pascals is  

\[
P_{\text{ext}} = 1.0\;\text{atm}=1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa}.
\]

Hence  

\[
w = -(1.01325\times10^{5}\;\text{Pa})(7.5\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^3)
   = -7.599\times10^{1}\;\text{J}
   \approx -7.6\times10^{1}\;\text{J}.
\]

\[
\boxed{-7.6\times10^{1}}\ \text{J}
\]

question: A proton and a negatively charged $\mu$ meson (called a muon) can form a short-lived species called a mesonic atom. The charge of a muon is the same as that on an electron and the mass of a muon is $207 m_{\mathrm{e}}$. Assume that the Bohr theory can be applied to such a mesonic atom and calculate the frequency associated with the $n=1$ to $n=2$ transition in a mesonic atom.
llm_output:
The Bohr energy levels for a hydrogen‑like atom with reduced mass \(\mu\) are  

\[
E_n=-\frac{\mu}{m_e}\,\frac{13.6\ \text{eV}}{n^{2}} .
\]

For a proton–muon atom  

\[
\mu=\frac{m_{\mu}m_{p}}{m_{\mu}+m_{p}}
      =\frac{207\,m_{e}\times 1836\,m_{e}}{207+1836}\,m_{e}
      =\frac{380052}{2043}\,m_{e}\approx 186.03\,m_{e}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\Delta E =E_{2}-E_{1}
        =13.6\frac{\mu}{m_e}\left(\frac{1}{2^{2}}-\frac{1}{1^{2}}\right)
        =13.6\frac{\mu}{m_e}\left(-\frac34\right)
        =10.2\frac{\mu}{m_e}\ \text{eV}
        \approx 10.2\times 186.03\ \text{eV}
        \approx 1.90\times10^{3}\ \text{eV}.
\]

Using \(1\ \text{eV}=h\nu\) with \(h=4.135667696\times10^{-15}\ \text{eV·s}\),

\[
\nu=\frac{\Delta E}{h}
    =\frac{1.90\times10^{3}\ \text{eV}}{4.135667696\times10^{-15}\ \text{eV·s}}
    \approx 4.59\times10^{17}\ \text{Hz}.
\]
